Message.Title: Asian stocks fell, wiping out its gains for the month,
Message.Msg: Asian stocks fell, with the regional benchmark index wiping out its gains for the month, as reports on Japanese retail sales and South Korean business confidence add to signs of an economic slowdown and investors doubt the Federal Reserve will announce further stimulus.

Message.Title: Samsung / Nokia / Apple or Google ? Which will be the first to buy Interdigital...
Message.Msg: Samsung / Nokia / Apple or Google ? Which will be the first to buy Interdigital.... - Based on the rough price of $221,000 per patent, InterDigital's patent portfolio alone could be worth around $4 billion . - The company Worth $107-$145/Share based on Motorola Mobility and Nortel Sales. - Apple could improve its position in LTE patents significantly by acquiring InterDigital. - IDCC owns 9% of all essential LTE patents. - John Paulson's fund has more than 4 Million of shares. Patents are becoming so valuable that Samsung / Nokia / Apple and Google Inc. may have to pay more than 100 percent premium to buy InterDigital Inc. Apple and Google are vying to obtain exclusive rights to the inventions used in almost every device from the iPhone to Google’s Android-based handsets. Because some of InterDigital’s patents are used in Apple’s iPhone and Google’s Android. This is a growing company with a strong core of assets that are very desirable to many others out there

Message.Title: Losses coming on Motorola Acquisition
Message.Msg: First GOOG has warned it must take huge charges later this year to lay off 20% of its worldwide Motorola employees. Now it also is basically conceding it must "lay off" the cable set box division as well. Its looking to sell it. It hired Barclays to try and sell it. But who's going to want to pay much for a no-growth and over time Obsolete Business? If GOOG can't get its price desired for selling the cable-set-top-box business, at some point it must write-down part of the GoodWill it paid to acquire Motorola. These costs along with the large layoffs will impact earnings growth in the next year.

Topic.Title: 2010:Brightcove Prsdnt: WebM Will Overtake H.264 in 1-2 Years

Message.Msg: Friday, July 27, 2012 Brightcove to buy Zencoder; CTO leaves for new venture By Patricia Resende The plan is to integrate Zencoder’s technology into Brightcove’s core video platform. The acquisition will enable Brightcove to deliver a premium option to customers and allow the company to offer Zencoder’s cloud-based encoding service as a standalone product, according to Allaire. In addition, Brightcove announced that its co-founder and CTO Bob Mason is leaving the company. “The Zencoder team is excited to join Brightcove,” said Jon Dahl, chief executive officer and co-founder of Zencoder, said in a prepared statement. “Our founding mission was to build the best suite of media processing services in the cloud, with a focus on powerful, API-based tools for developers. Brightcove shares this vision, and by joining forces, we believe that we will be well positioned to accelerate Zencoder’s growth.”

Message.Title: Google Inc's Android software: China smartphone market to overtake U.S. in 2012: research firm
Message.Msg: NEW YORK (Reuters) - China will overtake the United States as the world's biggest smartphone market this year, according to research firm IDC, which expects demand to grow for lower-priced smartphones based on Google Inc's Android software. IDC forecast that China's share of the smartphone market will increase to 26.5 percent this year from 18.3 percent last year, while U.S. market share declines to 17.8 percent from 21.3 percent. China's sales will be helped by the availability of Android devices priced at $100 or less due to intensifying competition among smartphone vendors, according to IDC. The research firm expects Chinese carriers to help sales by subsidizing phones. South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is the biggest maker of phones using Android around the world and also in the Chinese market. There it is trailed by domestic companies, including Huawei Technologies Co Ltd, ZTE Corp and Lenovo Group Ltd. In the U.S., growth is expected to slow this year because smartphones already make up the majority of shipments here. The United Kingdom, the next biggest smartphone market, will trail behind, with a 4.5 percent market share. India's market share is expected to be 2.5 percent in 2012 and will grow to 8.5 percent in 2016. (Reporting by Sinead Carew; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe)

Topic.Title: CIA giving AWAY free ON2 shareholders STOLEN products to the "artists"???

Message.Msg: Robert Hof, Contributor 8/30/2012 @ 8:03PM |493 views Google Shuts Off TV Ads Business After five years of trying to sell ads on television using the automated buying system that works so well for its signature search ads, Google has finally given up. In a blog post this afternoon from Shishir Mehrotra, VP of YouTube and video, the ad giant said it will shunt the group’s staff to other projects Mehrotra, who last year became ­YouTube’s vice president of product, envisions millions of online channels disrupting TV, just as cable’s 400 channels disrupted the four broadcast networks. “We want to be the host of that next generation of channels,” he says.
